A 6-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of persistent jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine since the second week of life. On examination, the infant has hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show the following: • Serum total bilirubin: 12 mg/dL (direct bilirubin: 8 mg/dL) • Liver enzymes: Elevated AST and ALT • Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT): Significantly elevated An ultrasound of the abdomen shows an absent gallbladder. A percutaneous liver biopsy demonstrates bile duct proliferation, portal fibrosis, and inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice, acholic stools, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show direct hyperbilirubinemia and elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). A hepatobiliary scintigraphy scan shows no excretion of radiotracer into the bowel even after 24 hours. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

A 45-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, associated with nausea and vomiting. Ultrasound shows multiple gallstones without signs of gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Oral dissolution therapy with ursodeoxycholic acid

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and needs to identify the boundaries of Calot's Triangle. Which of the following structures define the boundaries of Calot's Triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and cystic artery

options.label: B
options.text: Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and inferior border of the liver

options.label: C
options.text: Cystic duct, right hepatic artery, and inferior border of the liver

options.label: D
options.text: Common bile duct, cystic duct, and superior border of the pancreas

questions.correct_answer: A. Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and cystic artery
